Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Rapid: Activation of the Inner Continental Shelf In Response to the Great Mississippi/Atchafalaya River Flood of 2011
Award.AbstractNarration: The Mississippi River and Atchafalaya River are experiencing a historic flood of major geological significance. South Louisiana has one of the fastest land loss rates on any region on Earth, with much of the loss due to a lack of sediment delivery into the coastal zone. This flood is likely to deliver large amounts of sediments to the coastal zone, and therefore could potentially contribute to land building along the South Louisiana coast. This research is a rapid response to investigate whether the massive release of freshwater from the Atchafalaya River in late May, 2011 will lead to the development of a freshwater-dominated continental shelf environment and whether sediments released by the flood will initiate the development of a large mobile mud belt that will extend from the mouth of the Atchafalaya River westward along the Chenier Plain Coast. These hypotheses are being tested by examining the physical and geological oceanography of the inner continental shelf and determining the patterns of recently deposited sediments. The proposed research provides a rare opportunity to study the critical processes of sediment supply and land building in a coastal ecosystem. Broader impacts include support of two institutions in EPSCoR states and student training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the impacts of the Great Mississippi/Atchafalaya River of 2011 on the oceanography of the Gulf of Mexico. This is intellectually important because the MississippI River is the dominant pathway by which water, sediments, and nutrients are transported from the North American continent to the ocean. This is societally important because the Mississippi River is the one of the most economically important economic pathway in the United States. The river carries more tons of cargo than any other waterway in the United States, the Port of South Louisiana handles more tons of cargo than any other port in the nation, and the northern Gulf Coast is responsible for about 1/3 of the nation's seafood production and nearly 1/3 of the nation's oil infrastructure. Many of the pieces of economic vitality are threatened by land loss in coastal Louisiana, and reversing this land loss requires transporting sediments to the coastal zone and retaining these sediments in the coastal zone. 

Given the theoretical and practical value of sediments, we wanted to understand how water and sediment were transported during a large flood. We examined this question using multiple approaches. In short, we conducted a series of research cruises to measure how water and sediments moved through the system. Sediment samples were returned to the lab whre we measured the concentration of sediments in the water column. To understand how our results fit into the broader picture of the oceanography of the northern gulf coast, we used images from NASA satellite and USGS data on river gauges. 

       We found that this flood drastically impacted the oceanography of the continental shelf. First, it created a massive area in the ocean, almost 30 miles wide, and 10 miles long, where surface waters was fresh enough to drink. Second, the flood transported lots of sediment to the coastal ocean. Indeed, we demonstrated that the major impact of this flood was to move sedment that normally would have been trappoed in the inshore deltas to offshore regions. From a theoretical perspective, these results suggest that the importance of a large flood on this ocean are governed by the size of the flood, the geomotry of the channel and the return period of the event. From a practical perspective, these results sugget that in order for floods to be used to restore coastal Louisiana, engineering efforts are needed to effectively traps sediments in the nearshore zone. One example of such an engineering structure are the sediment retention devices (SREDs) that were installed in the West Bay Mississippi River Diversion prior to the flood. That area experienced unexpected and subtantial land growth following the flood, and results from this study and related work, indicate that these SREDs are partially responsible for this sediment retention. 

      Overall, this project both provided us with a unique opportunity to understand how large rivers function.  In so doing, we were able to better understand how to restore one of the United States' most economically important and culturally unique regions.
